Hi Aidan,

Welcome to the group.

2009/9/5 Aidan Morgan <aidos@...=
>:
>
> Thankyou for the clarification about the genome compatability metric=
s. I am
> currently working on a version of NEAT that will integrate with t=
he Neuroph
> Neural Network library in Java.

Interesting idea. I must look=
 into that project a bit more deeply.


> I must admit I have implemented t=
he=A0first version you described and it seems
> to work quite well, when I =
changed it to the=A0second version I get some
> strange behaviour:

Your fi=
rst problem is that you have too many species even with
equation (1). For a=
 population size of 150 you probably don't want any
more than 10-15 species=
 at most, certainly if you have a lot of
species with just one member somet=
hing is not quite right. It could be
that you just need to set the compatib=
ility threshold higher, what
SharpNeat1 (SN1) and other packages do is dyna=
mically adjust the
threshold at each generation to try and keep the number =
of species
near some target value. In fact SN1 uses a min and max number of=

species and only updates the threshold if the number is outside that
range=
; that helps prevent the number of species oscillating up and
down too much=
 (some heating thermostats use the same approach).

The fact that you see m=
ore species with equation (2) is exactly what I
would expect. If you think =
about two genomes both with many genes but
that are all different, so there=
 are no matching genes. (2) says that
the distance between them increases w=
ith the number of mismatched
genes. (1) on the other hand scales the distan=
ce to the range 0-1, so
slightly dissimilar genomes are about as distance f=
rom each other as
wildly different genomes.

When you switch from (1) to (2=
) the chances are that distance between
genomes is very much higher and the=
refore you need a higher
compatibility threshold, otherwise all of the geno=
mes are deemed to be
incompatible with other and thus placed into separate =
species.

If you start to consider matching genes then thinsg get worse. Th=
eir
distance isn't scaled adn so it can greatly exceed 1. Therefore
matchin=
g topologies with many matchign genes and thsu weight
differences can be de=
emed to be further apart than two genoems with
completely different topolog=
ies.

So personally I would say that (2) is the better equation and I would=

suggest that you switch over to (2) and then try and tackle the
problem of=
 too many species from there.



> How would this specie saturation affect =
the performance of NEAT? If we have
> a fixed population size, and after 14=
0 generations every population member
> is in a specie all on it's own what=
 affect will this have on the results of
> the remaining 360 generations? I=
f we use an elitist strategy (which I keep
> the best organism in each spec=
ie, and throw the rest away) then we won't be
> able to get any further tha=
t the results from the 140th generation?

Exactly. Another problem would be=
 that we can't produce offspring by
combining two parent from the species. =
We have to use asexual
reproduction 100% of the time or select a parent fro=
m another species
- which is less likely to produce fit offspring. There ar=
e probly
other issues as well.



> I am currently working with a similarit=
y metric for the speciation based on
> behaviour. Instead of using the "beh=
aviour" instead of the fitness score
> like the novelty search, or using a =
MOEA of the fitness and novelty I
> thought it would be interesting to try =
and speciate based on the behaviour
> and see how well that compares with n=
ovelty search and the MOEA approach of
> fitness and novelty. I will provid=
e some updates as I get further into my
> work.

Nice idea. What do you do?=
 Perhaps keep an array of network outputs
and compare them?



> This is my=
 first post to the group -=A0I did go back and read your other posts
> abou=
t the compatability metric from the archive, and a quick search didn't
> sh=
ow up anyone else seeing this behaviour. However I do apologise if I have
>=
 reposted something someone has already said.

No worries. BTW I do have a =
working version of NEAT usign k-means
clustering which is my attempt at imp=
roving speciation, particularly
the problem of too many or too ferw species=
 and how best to
dynamically adjust the compatibility threshold. I was inte=
nding to
cleanup the code a bit more and write some explanations before
rel=
easing it but I don't mind dropping a zip file somewhere if you or
anyone e=
lse wants to take a look now.

Regards,

Colin
